1F87198A74AC4A3B9FD0A43BC5B04DD8.description: describe the characteristics of the recognized kingdoms and their importance in ecosystems such as bacteria aiding digestion or fungi decomposing organic matter.

BD6BA4B0689D48A2963C85C9635330E2.description: describe the taxonomic system that categorizes organisms based on similarities and differences shared among groups; and

49DD0242A055461F88CB074396614E46.description: Organisms and environments. The student knows how the taxonomic system is used to describe relationships between organisms. The student is expected to:

0142034D2E9046EFAC3958B4D88307C8.description: describe and give examples of how natural and artificial selection change the occurrence of traits in a population over generations.

90C26045EC8A4255886A0C87FFC435DC.description: compare the results of asexual and sexual reproduction of plants and animals in relation to the diversity of offspring and the changes in the population over time; and

D5AA515D0CFE4C61AD50C5CD8444A0E7.description: describe the hierarchical organization of cells, tissues, organs, and organ systems within plants and animals;

F16D2FBB7743423EB381752AA5F4B9F1.description: identify and model the main functions of the systems of the human organism, including the circulatory, respiratory, skeletal, muscular, digestive, urinary, reproductive, integumentary, nervous, immune, and endocrine systems;

107F361D50E249D59686CE50E4A502DF.description: Organisms and environments. The student knows how systems are organized and function to support the health of an organism and how traits are inherited. The student is expected to:

23718D3D804E49529B8B1E7491CA7C7E.description: describe how ecosystems are sustained by the continuous flow of energy and the recycling of matter and nutrients within the biosphere.

B77A81A38D674CE38DBC8A8074A4C7B4.description: diagram the flow of energy within trophic levels and describe how the available energy decreases in successive trophic levels in energy pyramids; and

18C6A892566A40DBB8C2783552DF85EA.description: Organisms and environments. The student understands that ecosystems are dependent upon the cycling of matter and the flow of energy. The student is expected to:

E9B9B032238241778D5599E559DF730E.description: describe human dependence and influence on ocean systems and explain how human activities impact these systems.

56C8B3ABE1EC4D889B9A48BC8C9BBA37.description: analyze the beneficial and harmful influences of human activity on groundwater and surface water in a watershed; and

88642FBA2C214484ACA9675EA3C1BA1C.description: Earth and space. The student understands how human activity can impact the hydrosphere. The student is expected to:

CD0CD6152B7A46F5B877C0F9C01E95B2.description: describe how plate tectonics causes ocean basin formation, earthquakes, mountain building, and volcanic eruptions, including supervolcanoes and hot spots.

C6F86D81A5234ADEAD9C25797FEDDCAB.description: describe the evidence that supports that Earth has changed over time, including fossil evidence, plate tectonics, and superposition; and

6FD78A58093E480C9E07FC95C29D4DC6.description: Earth and space. The student understands the causes and effects of plate tectonics. The student is expected to:

C395E3D1FE214AA9BF30B82F3A39191B.description: analyze the characteristics of Earth that allow life to exist such as the proximity of the Sun, presence of water, and composition of the atmosphere.

E45749B31BAF40EEA0C4D760B2157E3B.description: describe how gravity governs motion within Earth's solar system; and

558A4619732D459C8EBA25D851137A2C.description: describe the physical properties, locations, and movements of the Sun, planets, moons, meteors, asteroids, comets, Kuiper belt, and Oort cloud;

3C4D629C11EF4CDAADA916B9BB32682E.description: Earth and space. The student understands the patterns of movement, organization, and characteristics of components of our solar system. The student is expected to:

E899216CA4E842CBB0DB6BBE091B0CBB.description: explain the relationship between temperature and the kinetic energy of the particles within a substance.

4B9780B434A94F1C8931C0033EC1CF25.description: investigate how thermal energy moves in a predictable pattern from warmer to cooler until all substances within the system reach thermal equilibrium; and

08B2DFF61C524C608B0CC683BBB37D2C.description: investigate methods of thermal energy transfer into and out of systems, including conduction, convection, and radiation;

EDFBC026393541A4A27EFC827C6AD892.description: Force, motion, and energy. The student understands the behavior of thermal energy as it flows into and out of systems. The student is expected to:

37FD56A145CA423A937CF33DB8663B27.description: analyze the effect of balanced and unbalanced forces on the state of motion of an object using Newton's First Law of Motion.

094451A3F1CA493F8E1E611D5942BCB8.description: measure, record, and interpret an object's motion using distance-time graphs; and

D74C46FBF6064774A21C0B533B965957.description: distinguish between speed and velocity in linear motion in terms of distance, displacement, and direction;

2F96EF447CF34FBE8F98671AB1026608.description: calculate average speed using distance and time measurements from investigations;

1CD4C5B80A4142478A45C7BC9D30193E.description: Force, motion, and energy. The student describes the cause-and-effect relationship between force and motion. The student is expected to:

850A275481B64A87837637C4DA4F5252.description: investigate and model how temperature, surface area, and agitation affect the rate of dissolution of solid solutes in aqueous solutions.

741BCF049BA4430A82B2C9C1EE7F0213.description: describe aqueous solutions in terms of solute and solvent, concentration, and dilution; and

66E479A6C1C94337A569BB56BFA6044E.description: distinguish between physical and chemical changes in matter;

E86B9DAACA4F458581077E9A506606D1.description: use the periodic table to identify the atoms and the number of each kind within a chemical formula;

F2B65BF075294ED2AA72D88EE4FFEBC5.description: compare and contrast elements and compounds in terms of atoms and molecules, chemical symbols, and chemical formulas;

7CA32BAA7C8F4CC693B3609000AAEFE0.description: Matter and energy. The student distinguishes between elements and compounds, classifies changes in matter, and understands the properties of solutions. The student is expected to:

F4AC6BBD446646A2B7FF273CCF08FA32.description: analyze and explain how factors or conditions impact stability and change in objects, organisms, and systems.

2A4C9975839A413792AD23AEF3A746C8.description: analyze and explain the complementary relationship between structure and function of objects, organisms, and systems; and

E6CDE306BCF640A48F03AFA97A58DCE6.description: analyze and explain how energy flows and matter cycles through systems and how energy and matter are conserved through a variety of systems;

CD5CF9888BE8409A8B608A725A0F6BFA.description: examine and model the parts of a system and their interdependence in the function of the system;

785468DC78D94ADB893370A28DD0A883.description: analyze how differences in scale, proportion, or quantity affect a system's structure or performance;

1B6CB4B376714B5299DE0268443F4B0B.description: identify and investigate cause-and-effect relationships to explain scientific phenomena or analyze problems;

70A1615AD1FD4C3DB30DF8F88E7CDF31.description: identify and apply patterns to understand and connect scientific phenomena or to design solutions;

5D57FA2A378E402B9376DB91C4B7C73B.description: Recurring themes and concepts. The student understands that recurring themes and concepts provide a framework for making connections across disciplines. The student is expected to:

1E2D01858C414669940165A7BF0D078C.description: research and explore resources such as museums, libraries, professional organizations, private companies, online platforms, and mentors employed in a science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) field to investigate STEM careers.

F98C1989B4FD495DB42D68CC5C292980.description: make informed decisions by evaluating evidence from multiple appropriate sources to assess the credibility, accuracy, cost-effectiveness, and methods used; and

8C178569BF0A4C9DACAF9ED4EAE22674.description: relate the impact of past and current research on scientific thought and society, including the process of science, cost-benefit analysis, and contributions of diverse scientists as related to the content;

173DCB32707847E8BD06FD35EDBED86F.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student knows the contributions of scientists and recognizes the importance of scientific research and innovation on society. The student is expected to:

E6EC96BBA6B5449484E66C04005FACE9.description: engage respectfully in scientific argumentation using applied scientific explanations and empirical evidence.

94C96B1A11A94015A53AB188E3799F6E.description: communicate explanations and solutions individually and collaboratively in a variety of settings and formats; and

73A2274FBACA4352BD6C4CAF352C40F3.description: develop explanations and propose solutions supported by data and models and consistent with scientific ideas, principles, and theories;

F4EB68D629BA405BAE2DC6F84B294FA0.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student develops evidence-based explanations and communicates findings, conclusions, and proposed solutions. The student is expected to:

16E41D6536634ECC9E10DB752F853912.description: use mathematical calculations to assess quantitative relationships in data; and

8B7060323F454F1188D16BC538503A31.description: analyze data by identifying any significant descriptive statistical features, patterns, sources of error, or limitations

972522CEBAFE4C7A84D3DECD7A5D89C5.description: identify advantages and limitations of models such as their size, scale, properties, and materials;

40D979ED3ED54510AB2EF313EC885F54.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student analyzes and interprets data to derive meaning, identify features and patterns, and discover relationships or correlations to develop evidence-based arguments or evaluate designs. The student is expected to:

9464FE4EE068469D8E68E85BAD5B2B6C.description: distinguish between scientific hypotheses, theories, and laws.

7C1FC133A1E34212A1EA87A061694A58.description: develop and use models to represent phenomena, systems, processes, or solutions to engineering problems; and

DBC6CCFD57834E31BA6A44321F32BC83.description: construct appropriate tables, graphs, maps, and charts using repeated trials and means to organize data;

49E04EDF77D342C7BDF4C6AD4B57D7DC.description: collect quantitative data using the International System of Units (SI) and qualitative data as evidence;

ABD4681FC1D448A98CCE76048F19F9BC.description: use appropriate tools such as graduated cylinders, metric rulers, periodic tables, balances, scales, thermometers, temperature probes, laboratory ware, timing devices, pH indicators, hot plates, models, microscopes, slides, life science models, petri dishes, dissecting kits, magnets, spring scales or force sensors, tools that model wave behavior, satellite images, hand lenses, and lab notebooks or journals;

98106CCB67814844B03F91C59EC99230.description: use appropriate safety equipment and practices during laboratory, classroom, and field investigations as outlined in Texas Education Agency-approved safety standards;

7D6DB904DCEE4E4B8A7F09705E5CEF8D.description: use scientific practices to plan and conduct descriptive, comparative, and experimental investigations and use engineering practices to design solutions to problems;

D85D02E1A03E42B9AD5CC7218A037C88.description: ask questions and define problems based on observations or information from text, phenomena, models, or investigations;

4691A2407163401EBE6FE7CBBBF2A2DB.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, asks questions, identifies problems, and plans and safely conducts classroom, laboratory, and field investigations to answer questions, explain phenomena, or design solutions using appropriate tools and models. The student is expected to:

071BFECFE9E145D1A3B3B85A00B13A11.description: Statements containing the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

BDB72E9CEBDC4D1393011E96A3DD6013.description: Recurring themes and concepts. Science consists of recurring themes and making connections between overarching concepts. Recurring themes include structure and function, systems, models, and patterns. All systems have basic properties that can be described in space, time, energy, and matter. Change and constancy occur in systems as patterns and can be observed, measured, and modeled. These patterns help to make predictions that can be scientifically tested. Models have limitations but provide a tool for understanding the ideas presented. Students analyze a system in terms of its components and how these components relate to each other, to the whole, and to the external environment.

574975C4B3D342C8BF9DC21FA093FA58.description: Science and social ethics. Scientific decision making is a way of answering questions about the natural world involving its own set of ethical standards about how the process of science should be carried out. Students distinguish between scientific decision-making practices and ethical and social decisions that involve science.

B4D63C2046B0403F82B6EF2F7DBA301C.description: scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well established and highly reliable explanations, but they may be subject to change as new areas of science and new technologies are developed.

28CEAFBBF52B4A1EB243D914A1F1ADC7.description: hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power that have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories; and

4ECC4A14AFAF4F468215E3F544AA6C33.description: inferences are conclusions reached on the basis of observations or reasoning supported by relevant evidence;

6D9906C8CB394481AC637B58C84D51B1.description: observations are active acquisition of either qualitative or quantitative information from a primary source through the senses;

EAD4EA8CE30A4272BCFD4D7151B54949.description: Scientific observations, inferences, hypotheses, and theories. Students are expected to know that:

2CF067C9A6A342159B6870DD7DD0FBE5.description: Nature of science. Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not currently scientifically testable.

266364929D654D0B99AE3849D39DA858.description: Organisms and environments. Students further their understanding of organisms as systems made up of cells organized into tissues, tissues into organs, and organs into organ systems by identifying the main functions of the organs within the human body. During both sexual and asexual reproduction, traits are passed on to the next generation. Students understand how traits in populations can change through the processes of natural and artificial selection. Students analyze how energy flows through trophic levels and how biodiversity impacts an ecosystem's sustainability. Students gain an understanding of the taxonomic classifications of organisms and how characteristics determine their classification.

E7BD8D5A2FFB4435872C5DC354C92C14.description: Earth and space. Students explore characteristics and organization of objects and the role of gravity within our solar system. Earth has a specific set of characteristics that allows life to exist. Students further their understanding of the geosphere by illustrating how Earth's features change over time through tectonic movement. Students investigate how humans depend on and affect the hydrosphere.

C1654C2161914681B6E2B9AD71F7ECF6.description: Force, motion, and energy. Students measure, calculate, graph, and investigate how forces impact linear motion. Students build upon their understanding of the laws of motions by exploring Newton's First Law of Motion. Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of molecules. Thermal energy is transferred by conduction, convection, or radiation in order to reach thermal equilibrium.

3345B4B01D974218A83CFD8CCE20FD26.description: Matter and energy. Students have prior experience with elements in Grade 6 and develop an understanding that compounds are also pure substances in Grade 7. Students investigate the differences between elements and compounds through observations, descriptions of physical properties, and chemical reactions. Students build upon their understanding of solutions by exploring aqueous solutions.

5957AAFAC428420D97A2298FD1D49B2F.description: Engineering practices. Students identify problems and design solutions using appropriate tools and models.

C58B1FA17B3F4ECDB3EAD284A588C214.description: Scientific practices. Students ask questions, plan and conduct investigations to answer questions, and explain phenomena using appropriate tools and models.

862F86E9B00646688AF0AE5E0489380D.description: Scientific and engineering practices. Scientific inquiry is the planned and deliberate investigation of the natural world using scientific and engineering practices. Scientific methods of investigation are descriptive, correlative, comparative, or experimental. The method chosen should be appropriate to the grade level and question being asked. Student learning for different types of investigations includes descriptive investigations, which have no hypothesis that tentatively answers the research question and involve collecting data and recording observations without making comparisons; correlative and comparative investigations, which have a hypothesis that predicts a relationship and involve collecting data, measuring variables relevant to the hypothesis that are manipulated, and comparing results; and experimental investigations, which involve processes similar to comparative investigations but in which a hypothesis can be tested by comparing a treatment with a control.

2FAE5A1FFECB4BCFAB50D1724102BF04.description: In Grades 6 through 8 Science, content is organized into recurring strands. The concepts within each grade level build on prior knowledge, prepare students for the next grade level, and establish a foundation for high school courses. In Grade 7, the following concepts will be addressed in each strand.
